title: Relates to increasing the availability of adult day health care programs in certain counties
summary: Relates to increasing the availability of adult day care programs in counties with a population of 130,000 and less than 140,000.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2450

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to increase the availability of adult day health care programs;
and providing for the repeal of such provisions upon expiration thereof

PURPOSE:
This legislation provides that any assisted living program
operating in a county with a population of more than one hundred
thirty thousand and less than one hundred forty thousand persons
based on the 2000 Federal Census shall be authorized to operate an
adult health care program.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
This bill provides that any assisted living
program operating in a county with a population of more than one
hundred thirty thousand and less than one hundred forty thousand
persons based on the 2000 Federal Census shall be authorized to
operate an adult day health care program. The Commissioner of Health
would be authorized to provide this increase for a specific period of
time as part of a demonstration program. The bill also provides for
annual reporting requirements and sets the expiration date for the
demonstration program at September 1, 2016.

EXISTING LAW:
Currently only residential health care facilities
(nursing homes) are authorized to operate adult day health care
programs.

JUSTIFICATION:
Adult day health care programs are cost-effective
alternatives to institutional long-term care and should be promoted
as many individuals are being denied the appropriate care that they
need.
This bill would allow certain assisted living programs to operate an
adult day health care program. This bill requires an annual report
which would contain the cost of the program including the savings to
the state and local governments, the number of persons served by the
program by county, a description of the demographic and clinical
characteristics of patients served by the program, and an evaluation
of the quality of care provided to persons served by the program.
Unless there is a cost savings to the state and local governments,
the program would be terminated upon receiving the findings of the
second report.

PRIOR LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
2009-2010: S.4807/A.8279 Referred to Health
2008:      S.8479-A/A.11546 Referred to Rules

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:

The fiscal implications of this legislation are
yet to be determined.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately and be deemed
repealed September 1, 2016; with provisions.
